case_name: Jahangiri Mal Kalu Ram v. Official Receiver

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated April 7, 1966 of the Punjab High Court at Chandigarh in Letters Patent No. 296 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated April 7, 1966 of the Punjab High Court at Chandigarh in Letters Patent No. 296 of. 1963.

facts.text: Appellants are two brothers and their sons who constituted a firm called Jahangiri Mal Kalu Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are two brothers and their sons. They companystituted a firm called Jahangiri Mal Kalu Ram.

facts.text: On 19-11-1956 appellants were declared insolvents and Official Receiver took possession of all their properties including the building in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: On 19-11- 1956 they were declared insolvents and the Official Receiver took possession of all their properties including the building in dispute.

facts.text: On 21-11-1956 the appellants filed an objection petition under s. 60 CPC read with section 4 of the Provincial Insolvency Act regarding possession of the building in dispute based on clause ccc.

anchor.surface_text: On 21-11-1956 the appellants filed an objection petition under s. 60 of the Code of Civil Procedure read with section 4 of the Provincial Insolvency Act in respect of taking the possession of the building in dispute basing this upon clause  ccc  above referred to.

facts.text: Official Receiver contended that the property in dispute is not a residential house but a shop and back portion given in trust for residential purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The Official Receiver companytended that the property in dispute is number a residential house but a shop and that the back portion of the building which companysists of a kitchen and raised platform etc., for placing water was given in trust to the petitioners for residential purposes at the time of taking the possession of the shop.

facts.text: Creditors contended that the property is a shop and not a residential house, even though appellants admitted to using back portion as residence.

anchor.surface_text: The creditors also companytended that the property in dispute is a shop and number a residential house, even though the appellants were admitted to be using the back portion of the shop as their residence.

facts.text: Trial Court held the building consists of two distinct units: shop opening in chowk and back structure as residence; exempted portion BCDE and upper storey.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court held that the entire building companysists of two distinct units, the one opening in the chowk of themandi being distinct business premises as a shop while theother structure on the back thereof is exclusively a residence hours The unit which is a shop has the, main hallwhich has two. apartments on account of the arched companyumns inthe middle, and the kotha immediately behind-the said half. I companysider this kotha to be an integral part of the shop because there is numberindication at the spot that it was an essential part of the residen- tial house.

facts.text: District Judge of Hissar on appeal by insolvents held the building is the main residential house and allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the insolvents the learned District Judge of Hissar held that there was numbermanner of doubt that the building in question is the main residential house of the insolvents and allowed the appeal.

facts.text: Single Judge on appeal by creditors held the building is a single one with portion used as shop, in conformity with legislature, allowed exemption.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the creditors a learned Single Judge observed Accepting the. finding of the Insolvency Judge that the shop has a separate access of its own it cannot be denied that the residential portion is companynected with it. The shop is in the ground floor and there is an opening in the Mandi but it is companynected with the residential portion on the same floor. The other portion of the building is entirely devoted to residential purposes. In the result he held It is only a portion of the ground floor which has been used for shops.

facts.text: Division Bench in Letters Patent Appeal allowed creditors' appeal, set aside Single Judge and District Judge, restored Insolvency Judge order, following Full Bench in Ude Bhan v. Kapoor Chand.

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal under the Letters Patent the Division Bench purporting to follow the Full Bench decision of that Court in Ude Bhan Ors. v. Kapoor Chand Ors.  1 , where it was held that if out of the main residential house belonging to a number-agriculturist judgment-debtor a portion is let out by him to a tenant, the whole house companyld number be said to be in his occupation, allowed the appeal and set aside the judgments. of the I earned Single Judge as well as the District Judge and restored the order of the Insolvency Judge.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with District Judge and Single Judge that building is single with downstairs portion used as shop opening on chowk Mandi Dabwali and public street.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully companysidered the facts of this case and are in agreement with the view of the learned District Judge as well as the learned Single Judge of the High Court that the building is a single one with a portion of it in the down stairs being used as a shop. That portion opens on the chowk Mandi Dabwali and there is another opening for regular entrance from a public street.

facts.text: No evidence that upstairs used for shop.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence that any portion of the upstairs is being used for the purpose of the shop.

facts.text: Building is the main residential house of the insolvents and occupied by them.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that this was the main residential house of the insolvents and it was occupied by them.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside Division Bench judgment, restored Single Judge and District Judge judgments.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the judgment of the Division Bench set aside and the judgments of the learned Single Judge and the learned District Judge are restored.

facts.text: Respondents to pay appellants costs.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents will pay the appellants companys.

facts.text: Appellants admitted to be using back portion of the shop as residence.

anchor.surface_text: even though the appellants were admitted to be using the back portion of the shop as their residence.

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, upheld the objection petition of the appellants in respect of the portion BCDE in the plan and the upper storey thereon, and dismissed it in respect of the rest of the building.

facts.text: Kotha is integral part of shop per Insolvency Judge.

anchor.surface_text: I companysider this kotha to be an integral part of the shop because there is numberindication at the spot that it was an essential part of the residen- tial house. To the companytrary, the staircase leading from the hall on to the roof of that kotha and the steps from the roof of that kotha leading to the roof of the hall and to the room on a portion thereof, show that the said kotha is an integral part of the shop itself.

clause ccc added to the proviso to sub- s. 1 of s. 60 of the Code of Civil Procedure by Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act 7 of 1934 as amended by Punjab Acts 12 of 1940 and 6 of 1942 exempting from attachment- One main residential-house and other buildings attached to it  with the material and the sites thereof and the land immediately appurtenant thereto and necessary for their enjoyment belonging to a judgment debtor other than an agriculturist and occupied by him Provi

concepts.interpretation: Exempts the entire main residential house occupied by the non-agriculturist judgment-debtor from attachment, including portions used by the debtor for business/shop purposes (distinguishing from portions let out to tenants, which do not qualify as occupied by the debtor). Applies to composite use common in the country.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ion of the main residential house of a judgment-debtor ceases to enjoy immunity from attachment, in case that portion is let out by the, judgment debt

issues.text: The question for decision in this appeal depends upon the interpretation of clause ccc added to the proviso to sub-s. 1 of s. 60 of the Code of Civil Procedure by Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act 7 of 1934 as amended by Punjab Acts 12 of 1940 and 6 of 1942 exempting from attachment- One main residential-house and other buildings attached to it with the material and the sites thereof and the land immediately appurtenant thereto and necessary for their enjoyment belonging to a judgment debtor other than an agriculturist and occupied by him

anchor.surface_text: in a Letters Patent Appeal. The question for decision in this appeal depends upon the interpretation of clause ccc added to the proviso to sub- s. 1 of s. 60 of the Code of Civil Procedure by Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act 7 of 1934 as amended by Punjab Acts 12 of 1940 and 6 of 1942 exempting from attachment- One main residential-house and other buildings attached to it  with the material and the sites thereof and the land immediately appurtenant thereto and necessary for their enjoyment  belonging to a judgment debtor other than an agriculturist and occupied by him Provi

issues.text: the question that has to be considered in this case

anchor.surface_text: gives no guidance in interpreting the question that has to be considered in this case. The question for decision in this case is whether if a portion of the residential house is occupied by the judgment-debtor himself for the purposes of a shop that portion ceases to be part of the residential house. It appears to us clear that it does not. In the circumstances and social conditions of this country it would be difficult to justify the conclusion that where a part of a residential house is used in connection with the business or profession of the owner of that house that portion ceases to be part of the residential house.

issues.text: The question for decision in this case is whether if a portion of the residential house is occupied by the judgment-debtor himself for the purposes of a shop that portion ceases to be part of the residential house

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision in this case is whether if a portion of the residential house is occupied by the judgment-debtor himself for the purposes of a shop that portion ceases to be part of the residential house. It appears to us clear that it does not. In the circumstances and social conditions of this country it would be difficult to justify the conclusion that where a part of a residential house is used in connection with the business or profession of the owner of that house that portion ceases to be part of the residential house. As is well-known, very often a lawyer might have his office room in his house, a doctor might have a consulting room in his house, an advocates library might occupy one of the rooms of his house.

issues.text: whether the building is a single one with a portion of it in the down stairs being used as a shop or consists of two distinct units

anchor.surface_text: upheld the objection petition of the appellants in respect of the portion BCDE in the plan and the upper storey thereon, and dismissed it in respect of the rest of the building. On appeal by the insolvents the learned District Judge of Hissar held that there was no manner of doubt that the building in question is the main residential house of the insolvents and allowed the appeal. On appeal by the creditors a learned Single Judge observed Accepting the. finding of the Insolvency Judge that the shop has a separate access of its own it cannot be denied that the residential portion is connected with it.

The unit which is a shop has the, main hall which has two. apartments on account of the arched columns in the middle, and the kotha immediately behind-the said hall.

The shop is in the ground floor and there is an opening in the Mandi but it is connected with the residential portion on the same floor.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC in agreement with the view of the Single Judge.

arguments.claim: Following Full Bench in Ude Bhan v. Kapoor Chand (portion let out to tenant means whole house not occupied by judgment-debtor), the shop portion of the building is not exempt from attachment even if other part used residentially.

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal under the Letters Patent the Division Bench purporting to follow the Full Bench decision of that Court in Ude Bhan Ors. v. Kapoor Chand Ors. , where it was held that if out of the main residential house belonging to a non-agriculturist judgment-debtor a portion is let out by him to a tenant, the whole house could not be said to be in his occupation, allowed the appeal and set aside the judgments.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: there is another opening for regular entrance from a public street. There is numberevidence that any portion of the upstairs is being used for the pu

arguments.court_reasoning: Conclusion does not follow from Full Bench or statute; Full Bench applies to portions let out (not occupied by debtor), not to portions used by debtor himself for shop.

arguments.claim: The building is a single one with a portion downstairs used as a shop opening on chowk Mandi Dabwali and public street; no evidence upstairs used for shop; no warrant for finding two distinct portions.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered the facts of this case and are in agreement with the view of the learned District Judge as well as the learned Single Judge of the High Court that the building is a single one with a portion of it in the down stairs being used as a shop. That portion opens on the chowk Mandi Dabwali and there is another opening for regular entrance from a public street.

arguments.claim: Clause (ccc) exempts the main residential house; there is no doubt the building is the main residential house of the insolvents occupied by them.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that what clause  ccc  exempts is the main residential house. There is no doubt that the building is the main residential house of the insolvents. The judgment of the Full Bench proceeds on the basis that when a portion of even a main residential house is let out to a tenant by the judgment-debtor that portion is not occupied by him and as occupation of the residential house by the judgment-debtor is one of the requirements of the statute is order to qualify for exemption from attachment the portion let out cannot be said to be occupied by the judgment-debtor and therefore does not qualify for exemption.

arguments.claim: A portion of the residential house occupied by the judgment-debtor himself for shop purposes does not cease to be part of the residential house.

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision in this case is whether if a portion of the residential house is occupied by the judgment-debtor himself for the purposes of a shop that portion ceases to be part of the residential house. It appears to us clear that it does not.

arguments.claim: In social conditions of this country, part of residential house used for business or profession by owner does not cease to be part of residential house (e.g., lawyer office, doctor consulting room).

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances and social conditions of this country it would be difficult to justify the conclusion that where a part of a residential house is used in connection with the business or profession of the owner of that house that portion ceases to be part of the residential house. As is well-known, very often a lawyer might have his office room in his house, a doctor might have a consulting room in his house, an advocates library might occupy one of the rooms of his house.

arguments.claim: Following Agha Jafar Ali Khan v. Radha Kishan: mere shop on ground floor does not convert whole building from residential house.

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab Court has taken the same view at least from the year 1951. In Agha Jafar Ali Khan V. Radha Kishan it was held that where the whole building is being used for the purposes of residence, the mere fact that there is a shop on the ground floor will not convert the building into something different from a residential house.

arguments.claim: Following Firm Ganga Ram v. Firm Jai Ram: entire house exempt where ground floor commercial and upper residential, due to composite user common in country; otherwise defeats purpose of law.

anchor.surface_text: In Firm Ganga Ram v. Firm Jai Ram where the ground floor of a building with three floors was being used for commercial purposes and the first and the second floors for residential purposes it was held that the judgment-debtor can claim immunity from attachment or sale, with respect to the entire house under the provisions of section 60 1 clause  ccc , where it is the only residential house belonging to them and occupied by them.

arguments.claim: Distinction maintained by Tek Chand J. between portion let out to tenants (not exempt) and portion used by owner for non-residential purpose (still part of residential house).

anchor.surface_text: It is interesting to note that in Punjab Mercantile Bank Limited  in liquidation  Jullundur City v. Messrs General Typewriter Co., Jullundur City   Tak Chand, J. who gave the above judgment held that where the judgment-debtor was residing in the greater part of the house two chabaras on the first floor let out to tenants were not exempt from attachment and sale.

arguments.claim: The facts bring the case squarely within the scope of Section 60(1) clause (ccc); whole building exempt from attachment.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that this was the main residential house of the insolvents and it was occupied by them. The facts of the case bring it squarely within the scope of the section and the whole building is, therefore, exempt from attachment.

holdings.text: the building is a single one with a portion of it in the down stairs being used as a shop. That portion opens on the chowk Mandi Dabwali and there is another opening for regular entrance from a public street. There is no evidence that any portion of the upstairs is being used for the purpose of the shop. Therefore, there is no warrant for the finding of the Insolvency Judge that the building is in two distinct portions.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered the facts of this case and are in agreement with the view of the learned District Judge as well as the learned Single Judge of the High Court that the building is a single one with a portion of it in the down stairs being used as a shop. That portion opens on the chowk Mandi Dabwali and there is another opening for regular entrance from a public street.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court agrees with District Judge and Single Judge findings after considering facts; no evidence supports distinct units.

holdings.text: this conclusion does not follow from the judgment of the Full Bench or from the language of the statute.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed the learned Judges of the Division Bench did not differ from the finding of the first appellate court and the second appellate court on this point. They seem to accept this finding and proceed on that basis. Their reasoning was that if a portion of the main residential house of a judgment-debtor ceases to enjoy immunity from attachment, in case that portion is let out by the, judgment debtor to a tenant, it would necessarily follow that the. shop portion of a building, the other part of which is being used for residential purpose would not be exempt from attachment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Division Bench misapplied Full Bench precedent (Ude Bhan) which concerns letting out to tenants, not owner occupation for shop.

holdings.text: what clause ccc exempts is the main residential house.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that what clause ccc exempts is the main residential house.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of clause (ccc) proviso to s.60(1) CPC.

holdings.text: The question for decision in this case is whether if a portion of the residential house is occupied by the judgment-debtor himself for the purposes of a shop that portion ceases to be part of the residential house. It appears to us clear that it does not.

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision in this case is whether if a portion of the residential house is occupied by the judgment-debtor himself for the purposes of a shop that portion ceases to be part of the residential house. It appears to us clear that it does not. In the circumstances and social conditions of this country it would be difficult to justify the conclusion that where a part of a residential house is used in connection with the business or profession of the owner of that house that portion ceases to be part of the residential house.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear from statute language and social conditions (examples: lawyer office, doctor room); distinguishes tenant letting; follows precedents like Agha Jafar Ali Khan, Firm Ganga Ram.

holdings.text: There is no doubt that this was the main residential house of the insolvents and it was occupied by them. The facts of the case bring it squarely within the scope of the section and the whole building is, therefore, exempt from attachment.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that this was the main residential house of the insolvents and it was occupied by them. The facts of the case bring it squarely within the scope of the section and the whole building is, therefore, exempt from attachment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies clause (ccc) to undisputed facts of single main house occupied by debtors including shop portion used by them.

holdings.text: Such use does not make the residential house cease to be a residential house or the portion so used as no part of the residential house.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms distinction upheld in precedents between let-out portions (not occupied by debtor) and owner-used non-residential portions (still occupied by debtor).

precedents.citation: Agha Jafar Ali Khan V. Radha Kishan 1 [...] A.I.R. 1951 Punjab 433.

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab Court has taken the same view at least from the year 1951. In Agha Jafar Ali Khan V. Radha Kishan 1  it was held that where the whole building is being used for the purposes of residence, the mere fact that there is a shop on the ground floor will number companyvert the building into something different from a residential house. The judgment of the Full Bench mentions that it is number clear in that case whether the shop portion of the building was in the possession of the judgment-debtor or was rented out by him.

precedents.cited_proposition: where the whole building is being used for the purposes of residence, the mere fact that there is a shop on the ground floor will not convert the building into something different from a residential house

A.I.R. 1957 Punjab 293. only residential house belonging to them and occupied by them It is instructive to refer to a portion of the discussion The companyditions in our companyntry are such which admit of a companyposite user of the same building.

precedents.case_name: Firm Ganga Ram v. Firm Jai Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: where the ground floor of a building with three floors was being used for commercial purposes and the first and the second floors for residential purposes the judgment-debtor can claim immunity from attachment or sale with respect to the entire house under section 60(1) clause ccc where it is the only residential house belonging to them and occupied by them

precedents.citation: Punjab Mercantile Bank Limited in liquidation Jullundur City v. Messrs General Typewriter Co., Jullundur City [...] 1 1962 P. L. R. 10 8 1.

anchor.surface_text: It is interesting to numbere that in Punjab Mercantile Bank Limited  in liquidation  Jullundur City v. Messrs General Typewriter Co., Jullundur City   Tak Chand, J. who gave the above judgment held that where the judgment-debtor was residing in the greater part of the house two chabaras on the first floor let out to tenants were number exempt from attachment and sale. To the same effect is the judgment of the Full Bench relied on by the Division Bench in this case. Tek Chand, J. has kept clear in his mind the distinction between a case where a portion of the residential house is let out and a portion used by the owner himself, though for a purpose other than residential. Such use does number make the residential house cease to be a residential house or the portion so used as number part of the residential house.  1  1962 P. L. R. 10 8 1.

precedents.case_name: Punjab Mercantile Bank Limited in liquidation Jullundur City v. Messrs General Typewriter Co., Jullundur City
precedents.cited_proposition: where the judgment-debtor was residing in the greater part of the house two chabaras on the first floor let out to tenants were not exempt from attachment and sale

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered the facts of this case and are in agreement with the view of the learned District Judge as well as the learned Single Judge of the High Court that the building is a single one with a portion of it in the down stairs being used as a shop. That portion opens on the chowk Mandi Dabwali and there is another opening for regular entrance from a public street.

The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the judgment of the Division Bench set aside and the judgments of the learned Single Judge and the learned District Judge are restored. The respondents will pay the appellants companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding rejects a conclusion as part of deciding the interpretive issue posed

anchor.surface_text: Indeed the learned Judges of the Division Bench did not differ from the finding of the first appellate court and the second appellate court on this point. They seem to accept this finding and proceed on that basis. Their reasoning was that if a portion of the main residential house of a judgment-debtor ceases to enjoy immunity from attachment, in case that portion is let out by the, judgment debtor to a tenant, it would necessarily follow that the. shop portion of a building, the other part of which is being used for residential purpose would not be exempt from attachment.

The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the judgment of the Division Bench set aside and the judgments of the learned Single Judge and the learned District Judge are restored. The respondents will pay the appellants companyts.

edges.explanation: Adjacent spans where h3's interpretation of exemption explains why the conclusion in h2 does not follow from the statute
h3 defines exemption for main residential house, which h5 applies to identify the house as such
Holding interprets the exemption under clause ccc central to the issue

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that what clause ccc exempts is the main residential house.

The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the judgment of the Division Bench set aside and the judgments of the learned Single Judge and the learned District Judge are restored. The respondents will pay the appellants companyts.

The question for decision in this case is whether if a portion of the residential house is occupied by the judgment-debtor himself for the purposes of a shop that portion ceases to be part of the residential house. It appears to us clear that it does not. In the circumstances and social conditions of this country it would be difficult to justify the conclusion that where a part of a residential house is used in connection with the business or profession of the owner of that house that portion ceases to be part of the residential house.

The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the judgment of the Division Bench set aside and the judgments of the learned Single Judge and the learned District Judge are restored. The respondents will pay the appellants companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 that facts within scope supports application of c1
Holding applies the section to facts, resolving the interpretive question

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that this was the main residential house of the insolvents and it was occupied by them. The facts of the case bring it squarely within the scope of the section and the whole building is, therefore, exempt from attachment.

The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the judgment of the Division Bench set aside and the judgments of the learned Single Judge and the learned District Judge are restored. The respondents will pay the appellants companyts.
